newsitem.title: SLOVAKIA: Slovak gas monopoly denies Nafta holdings.
newsitem.headline: Slovak gas monopoly denies Nafta holdings.

text.p: Slovensky Plynarensky Priemysel s.p. (SPP), the state monopoly gas distributor, on Friday denied market rumours it was involved in a recent privatisation deal with gas storage firm Nafta a.s..

Earlier in August, the Slovak state privatisation agency the National Property Fund (NPF) said it had sold its 45.9 percent stake in Nafta, worth more than three billion crowns, for a mere 500 million crowns to an anonymous domestic firm.
The sale at around 400 crowns per share, was far below Nafta's then-market price of about 2,150 crowns per share.

"SPP has nothing to do with it," Viliam Mikulas, SPP's Economy and Trade division director, told Reuters. "Even if we participated in Nafta privatisation we would be interested in its storage tanks only, not the whole firm."
"We had submitted an unsuccessful privatisation bid for the tanks in the past but this time we had not been even offered that," Mikulas added.
Speculation swept through the market that the buyer might have been either SPP, or German Ruhrgas AG, which has also denied involvement in the deal, or someone in "high political circles".
SPP is Nafta's largest customer, currently renting well over a half of its storage facilities.

"We don't know what Nafta's future strategy will be but if it starts behaving immorally, we have prepared a whole range of other possibilities regarding storage and fund-raising," Mikulas noted, declining to comment further.
Industry sources said SPP is believed to be helping finance Nafta's strategic investment projects. As a customer it would be unlikely to pay market prices to Nafta.
"We depend on each other," Mikulas added.
